summary: This document is an email from Bruce A. Green, a legal ethics expert, to the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding Ghislaine Maxwell's sentencing. Green discusses the implications of a victim's impact statement from an unnamed individual, emphasizing the need for the prosecution to consider the credibility of this individual's testimony, especially in light of a sealed deposition that raises questions about her reliability.

persons.name: Bruce A. Green
persons.context: Bruce A. Green provides an expert opinion on the ethical obligations of prosecutors regarding the credibility of a victim's statement in Ghislaine Maxwell's sentencing.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Alan Dershowitz is mentioned as the individual who retained Bruce A. Green to provide legal ethics opinions regarding the case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Ghislaine Maxwell is the accused in the case, and the document discusses her upcoming sentencing.

persons.name: Virginia Giuffre
persons.context: Virginia Giuffre is referenced as a potential victim who may submit a statement for the sentencing, and her credibility is questioned based on her deposition.

persons.name: Maurene Comey
persons.context: Maurene Comey is one of the AUSAs addressed in the email regarding the case.

persons.name: Alison Moe
persons.context: Alison Moe is another AUSA addressed in the email regarding the case.

persons.name: Alex Rossmiller
persons.context: Alex Rossmiller is also addressed in the email as part of the U.S. Attorney's Office.

events.title: Email Regarding Sentencing
events.description: Bruce A. Green sends an email to the U.S. Attorney's Office discussing the implications of a victim's impact statement for Ghislaine Maxwell's sentencing.

locations: One Saint Andrews Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Bruce A. Green has been retained by Alan Dershowitz to provide legal ethics opinions regarding Ghislaine Maxwell's sentencing.
Virginia Giuffre's credibility is questioned based on her recent civil deposition testimony.
The U.S. Attorney's Office has a professional responsibility to consider the credibility of any witness it intends to rely on in court.
The email discusses the ethical obligations of prosecutors regarding candor to the court.
The document emphasizes the importance of protecting the court from relying on false information.
